abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Second Telecommunications Project in
            Burundi. The sector objectives at the start of the program
            were to strengthen further Office national des
            telecommunications (ONATEL)'s ability to: (a) increase
            operational efficiency and quality of service; (b) ensure
            that revenues would cover operating costs and contribute
            significantly to investments; (c) generate tax revenues for
            Government; (d) extend services to rural areas; and (e)
            expand facilities to meet expressed demand. In spite of the
            difficult environment, the performance of both the Borrower
            and the Bank in implementing the project was generally
            satisfactory, as the objectives have mainly been attained.
            The project outcome is satisfactory, though its rural
            network component was only partially implemented. The key
            lessons learned are as follows: (a) In a developing country
            with a high risk of economic and political turmoil,
            supervision missions should be unfailingly as frequent as
            twice a year to guide the implementation of the project.
            (b) Technical assistance has to be focused selectively and
            delivered in such a way that it can be absorbed with regards
            to the skills, size and availability (risk of turnover) of
            the staff of the entity, in order to avoid waste and
            frustration. (c) The audit requirement is an excellent
            covenant, provided the Bank enforce the recommendations
            flagged by the auditors to remedy accounts deficiencies, or
            decide to suspend the credit, even if difficult
            circumstances make it necessary to carry the supervision in
            a neighboring country but it should be qualified to demand
            that the entity remedy the deficiencies flagged by the
            auditors, through its own staff or external help. d) The
            institutional dialogue should take into account the country
            realities and the sustainability of any proposed liberalized scheme.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Telecommunications Project is
            an integral part of the Government's 1987-91 sectoral
            investment program. It is intended to increase ONATEL's
            (Office National des Telecommunications) operating and
            financial efficiency, improve the quality and reliability of
            services and partially meet unsatisfied demand. To support
            these objectives the project consists of technical
            assistance in planning, maintenance, financial control and
            staff training. In addition, telephone equipment will be
            used to reduce local call congestion, and to expand
            international services as well as telex facilities. The
            project also includes pilot assistance to reform the postal
            sector and to support basic sector investments.
